awd_titl_txt: ATD: Collaborative Research: Adaptive and Rapid Spatial-Temporal Threat Detection over Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop innovative machine learning and statistical algorithms for detecting, preventing, and responding to threats over networks. Two concrete applications are monitoring the threat of multi-antibiotic-resistant (MDR) gonorrhea from a network of clinics across the United States and monitoring HIV transmission in clusters of patients. The research has impact in many other practical applications, including biosurveillance, engineering, homeland security, finance, and public health, where large-scale spatial-temporal data streams are collected with the aim of rapid detection and prevention of threats. The research aims to develop crucial scalable algorithms and methods to effectively and efficiently monitor, analyze, and optimize responses in these situations. In addition, the project will integrate research and education by infusing the research findings into the curriculum and by involving Ph.D. students in research.  

This project aims to develop innovative algorithms for rapid threat detection by combining spatial-temporal models, ordinary differential equation (ODE) models with change-point detection, and multi-armed bandit and ensemble methods when monitoring large-scale spatial-temporal data over networks. In particular, efficient scalable algorithms are developed in three interrelated research tasks, including (1) rapid detection of threats by combining a "background + anomaly + noise" decomposition framework with sequential change-point detection; (2) predictive analytics of threats by applying multi-armed bandit algorithms and adaptive sampling in the changing environments to assess increasing risks at the population level; and (3) prescriptive analytics of threats by developing nested ensemble models based on calibrated ODE and data-driven spatial-temporal models so as to better assess the effects of prevention/intervention actions. Results of the project are expected to significantly advance the state of the art in spatial-temporal models, online learning, streaming data analysis, and large-scale inference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
From the technical aspects, this project develops algorithms under the following practical settings. 

  1. In the first line of work, we developed efficient hotspots detection algorithms based on tensor decomposition algorithm by decomposing the data into the background, sparse hotspots, and residuals. To make sure the proposed algorithm can be applied to a broader setting. Many applications are studied, including detecting hot spots in smooth spatial backgrounds, multiple tensor subspaces (clusters), low-rank backgrounds, etc. We also integrate these methods into the sparse hypothesis testing and change point detection methods (such as the CUSUM procedure) to monitor the residuals so as to detect and localize hot spots. Finally, the network structures have also been considered so that similar patterns are shared on the neighborhood nodes.
  2. In the second line of work, we focus on adaptive sequential change point detection with limited sampling resources. To address this, we have extended the previous decomposition settings into the probabilistic settings. For example, we have developed a Bayesian version of the hotspot decomposition methods to quantify the uncertainty of the detected hotspots. The uncertainty of the hotspot estimation can be used for future tasks such as adaptive resource allocation for hotspot detection based on the multi-armed bandit problems. Several useful application areas that we have developed include the test kit distribution for COVID-19 hotspot detection. Furthermore, we have also proved asymptotically the anomaly will converge to the true anomaly.
  3. In the third line of research, we focus on developing deep neural networks for more complex priors for anomaly detection. For example, we have developed two monitoring statistics based on variational autoencoders. To detect anomalies based on more complex spatio-temporal models, we have developed deep spatio-temporal decomposition methods based on spatial-temporal deep autoencoders. Finally, these methods have been applied to manufacturing defect inspection and abnormal cardinal detection.

The proposed method can potentially impact spatio-temporal hotspot detection, which can significantly impact the field of manufacturing systems, public health surveillance, transportation systems, etc. Through the Washington Department of Health collaboration, we will work on implementing some of the developed algorithms into HIV surveillance. 

Throughout the progress of the project, 10 peer-reviewed journal papers and 2 conference papers have been published. Partially supported by the project, 2 Ph.D. students have graduated.
